text: 1 Neuroscience is the study of how the brain and nervous system affect our mental  processes and our behavior.  2 Neuroscience is the study of how the brain and nervous system affect our mental  processes and our behavior.  Nervous system = an electrochemical system of communication within the body that uses  cells called neurons to convey information. The Nervous system in divided into two: Central Nervous System (brain and spinal cord;  decision‐maker) and the peripheral nervous system (everything else; responsible for  gathering information and transmitting CNS decisions to other body parts) The peripheral nervous system has sensory neurons = neurons that transmit information  from the sense organs to the central nervous system AND motor neurons = neurons that  transmit commands from the brain to the muscles of the body The peripheral nervous system also has two parts: the somatic nervous system and the  autonomic nervous stem: • The somatic nervous system is the branch of the peripheral nervous system that  governs sensory and voluntary motor action in the body…it allows us to control our  bodies in a deliberate, flexible way 3 • The autonomic nervous system is the branch of the peripheral nervous system that  primarily governs involuntary organ functioning and actions in the body…automatically  regulating some body functions, thus freeing our conscious resources for other efforts.  • The autonomic nervous system is then further divided into the parasympathetic  and sympathetic nervous systems.  • Parasympathetic Nervous System = the branch of the nervous system most active  during times of normal functioning = keeps heart rate, blood pressure,  respiration, etc. at normal levels (rest and digest) • Sympathetic Nervous System = the branch of the autonomic nervous system most  active during times of danger or stress = heart rate increases, breathing becomes  more rapid, blood pressure increases, digestion slows and blood goes to muscles • Helps prepare us to defend the body from threat (fight or flight) • Plays an important role in the response to stress 345 The human brain has developed over the course of three distinct versions of itself. Brain 1.0 is the hindbrain. The hindbrain is directly above the spinal cord. It is the ”primitive” part of the brain, it manages basic life-sustaining functions. It includes the brainstem. Brain 2.0 is the midbrain. The midbrain is responsible for making connections between the basic functions of the hindbrain and the complex mental processes of the forebrain. Brain 3.0 is the forebrain. The Forebrain takes up most of the top part of the skill. It is responsible for complex mental functions, such as problem- solving, thinking, remembering, and language 6 The forebrain is our most recent and most advanced level of brain tissue, and it contains many different structures: • the thalamus (part of the forebrain that functions as a sensory relay station, also responsible for REM sleep…helps regulate the attention we pay to things that stimulate our senses) • the hypothalamus(part of the forebrain that plays a role in maintaining homeostasis in the body, involving sleep, body temperature, sexual behavior, thirst, hunger; also the point where the nervous system intersects with the endocrine system) • Cortex= thin, wrinkled layer of tissue that covers the outside of the 2 hemispheres of the brain. • Limbic system = a system of structures that govern certain aspects of emotion, motivation and memory…it regulates basic emotional reactions Each of these plays different roles in both psychological and physiological functioning. You may want to make some flashcards to help you remember which is which. 7 Also please remember that the brain is vastly more complicated than we are presenting here, and you are getting a very basic introduction to brain structures. You can study the brain for years before you will have an advanced understanding of its functions and its vast potential. 7 • the limbic system (which includes the amygdala and hippocampus) • The limbic system is a system of structures that govern certain aspects of emotion, motivation and memory…it regulates basic emotional reactions • Amygdala (lizard brain) = A part of the limbic system that plays a role in the emotions of fear and aggression. Plays a role in how we perceive and respond to emotional stimuli. Part of emotional warning system that helps us avoid danger (having no fear = bad) • A damaged amygdala can result in difficulty interpreting emotions in facial expressions (esp fear and anger). • Individuals diagnosed with autism spectrum disorders have been shown to experience abnormal patterns of amygdala activation when looking at faces expressing fear. • Hippocampus= a part of the brain that plays a role in the transfer of information from short- to long-term memory 8 • Famous case of HM, who had damage done to his hippocampus to treat severe epilepsy. After, he was unable to form new memories. He has his pre-surgery memories and could hold things in consciousness for very short periods of time (momento) • London taxi driver study = were shown to have significantly larger hippocampi than bus drivers (complicated map vs single route). The longer the taxi drivers had been driving, the bigger their hippocampus 89 • Neuroplasticity– the nervous system’s ability to rewire its structures as a result of experience. • Taxi drivers • Stress hormones can negatively impact hippocampus • Some evidence that people who practice meditation have larger hippocampi than non-meditators 10 The Cortex  (also cerebral cortex) – the thin wrinkled layer of tissue that covers the outside  of the brain (2 hemispheres).  • Responsible for the highest levels of processing (planning, decision making, language,  perception) • Wrinkles and folds allow more cortical area in less space • Humans have the most developed cortex of all known organisms • Humans have more complex cortex than BOTH cats and zombies 11 There is no such thing as an unimportant brain structure, but the cerebral cortex is the most advanced and proportionately the largest structure. It is so large that it is divided into two halves (or hemispheres) and four areas (called lobes). This means there are eight total lobes (four on the left and four on the right). The left and right hemispheres may each have more input into different functions—this is called lateralization—but avoid falling for the myth that people are either “right-brained” or “left-brained.” • Lateralized functions of the brain = functions of the right and left lobes are somewhat different. (example of Wernicke’s area and Broca’sarea – language-related areas on the L side of the brain…damage to certain areas of the L brain can compromise the ability to produce or comprehend speech…not so with R side) • Brains tend to be wired in a contralateral fashion = right side governs left side of the body and vice versa (tends to be contralateral, but not everything is) • R and L sides used to be seen as having rather divided functions (L for 12 verbal and R for spatial), but newer studies indicated that functions are not divided up so clearly. In reality, both sides work together and perform complementary functions. Different lobes and their unique functions. • About 25% of the cortex is dedicated to sensori-motor functioning; the remaining 75% are dedicated to higher order processes (such as planning and decision making) that require integrating information = Association Cortex • Frontal Lobe = much of the frontal lobe is association cortex • Famous example of Phineas Gage, who had a metal rod go through the front of his head, damaging the prefrontal cortex • Survived, but had dramatic personality change = became more impulsive, emotionally volatile and irresponsible • Seems that the damage impacted his emotion regulation, planning and good judgement abilities • Motor cortex = band across the back of the frontal lobe that governs execution of motor movement (contralateral) • Parietal Lobe – also has a lot of association areas. Has Somatosensory cortex = strip of cortex in front of parietal lobe that governs sense of touch • Occipital lobe – visual cortex • Temporal lobe – auditory cortex; comprehension of speech (Wernicke’s area) 121314 The most basic unit of communication in the nervous system is the neuron. It transmits information so that different parts of the system can stay in touch with other parts. It helps us sense the world around us and initiate movement and, in many cases, is crucial for the automatic processes that take place in your body without you having any control over them. Neuron= cells in the nervous system that transmit information. = how brain communicates within itself and with the rest of the body There are also glia cells in the brain that are important for brain functioning. Glia Cells = brain cells that provide important support for the neurons and are involved in the formation of myelin • Very important for brain functioning • Maintain chemical environment, secrete cerebrospinal fluid, help repair neural damage, form myelin Myelin = fatty, waxy substance that insulates portions of some neurons in 15 the nervous system • Made up of glia cells • Protect neuron and speed up signals • Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a disease that involves the loss of myelin = neural signals are slowed or stopped = difficulty moving and an eventual breakdown of sensory signals. “orders sent to and from the brain lost along the way) 15 “Our body’s neural information system is complexity built from simplicity” (Myers and Dewall, 2016). In order to understand how neurons work, you must first be familiar with the basic parts, or structures, of a neuron. See how your authors describe the following parts of a neuron: - cell body = holds the nucleus and DNA - Dendrites= Branch like structures on the head of the neuron that receive incoming signals from other neurons *Dendrites listen, axons speak - Axon= long tail-like structure growing out of the cell body of a neuron that carries action potentials (electrically charged signals) that convey information from the cell body to the synapse. Axon usually covered in segments of myelin = myelin sheath (or myelinated) - Vary in length depending on function (from less than 1mm to almost a meter) 16 - The tail end of the axon splits into branches, with axon bulbs at the end of each branch - axon bulb and vesicles = bulbs at the end of the axon branches that contain vesicles (sacs) of neurotransmitters - Neurotransmitters= chemical messengers that carry signals across the small space between neurons. - synapse(and synaptic gap)= The connection formed between 2 neurons when the axon bulb of one neuron comes into close proximity with the dendrite of another - Don’t quite touch, so the space between is called the synaptic gap - In reality a synapse can occur at many points along the neuron (e.g. cell body). Most textbooks keep things simple with simple head-to-tail example. 1617 It is important to remember that neurons don’t touch each other; they are separated by a microscopic space called the synaptic gap. Presynaptic neuron = neuron sending the signal at the synapse Postsynaptic neuron = neuron receiving the signal at the synapse Many, many synapses in the brain because each neuron can connect with several thousand other neurons Neurons in the brain use electrochemical signals to communicate • When a neuron “fires” electrochemical signals are sent down the axon, causing neurochemicals to be released by the axon bulbs into the synaptic space. • The dendrites of the receiving neuron (postsynaptic neuron) have special receptorsthat can bind with neurotransmitters • Different neurochemicals have different receptors, like a lock and key • Some neurotransmitters excite the receiving neuron (make it more likely to fire); and some inhibit it (make it less likely to fire) • When the neuron reaches ta certain level of electrochemical excitement, it 18 fires Reuptake– the process through which neurotransmitters are recycled back into the presynaptic neuron • After a neuron fires, not all neurotransmitters will bind with receptors • They float around in the synapse and need to be cleaned up • Resupplies presynaptic neuron • Cleans up so that just the right amount of neurotransmitter is available to do the job….so that when the neurotransmitters are cleared from the receptors there isn’t another chance to duplicate the signal by firing again 18 Many psychopharmaceuticals (drugs used to treat psychological disorders) work by  adjusting the balance of neurotransmitters in the brain  Neuromodulators – chemical compounds that affect neurosignaling without directly  causing the neuron to fire The same chemical can sometimes act as a neurotransmitter, a neuromodulator, or  hormone depending on the context in which it is operating • Acetylcholine (ACh) – a neurotransmitter related to muscle movement and perhaps  consciousness, learning, and memory • In junctions between motor neurons and skeletal muscles; when released to our  muscle cell receptors, muscle contracts • First neurotransmitter discovered • People with Alzheimer’s experience a loss of neurons that release ACh into their  synapses • Dopamine – neurotransmitter that plays a role in reward, movement, motivation,  learning, and attention • Makes some activities (sex, eating, some drug use) very pleasurable and  rewarding  19 • Parkinson’s is linked to loss of neurons in areas high in dopamine, treatment  indirectly increases dopamine • Schizophrenia is associated with too much dopamine, drugs treat by blocking  action of dopamine • Serotonin – a neurotransmitter that plays a role in many different behaviors, including  sleep arousal, mood, eating, and pain perception • Low levels of serotonin have been linked to several mental health and behavioral  disorders (e.g., depression) • One type of commonly used psychopharmaceutical is the selective serotonin  reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) – treat depression, eating disorders, compulsive  disorders • Norepinephrine (NOR) – a neurotransmitter that plays a role in regulating sleep arousal  and mood • Some drugs that treat depression also target NOR • Plays a role in the functioning of the endocrine system • Gamma amino butyric acid (GABA)– The body’s chief inhibitory neurotransmitter, which  plays a role in regulating arousal and pain (arousal here means general energy level and  alertness) • Plays an essential role in brain functioning • Loss of GABA can produce seizures – w/o GABA to inhibit neural signals, arousal  levels become too high • Some anti‐convulsant drugs work by preventing breakdown of GABA • Drugs that increase GABA often used to calm and sedate (benzodiazepines,  barbiturates, alcohol)  • Glutamate – chief excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain, found @ more than 50% of  synapses • However, too much excitement caused by glutamate (from say a brain injury) can  cause cell death • Endorphins – neuromodulators that act as natural painkillers • Similar chemically to opiates • Endocrine System = a chemical system of communication in the body that uses chemical  messengers called hormones to affect organ function and behavior Slower and more long lasting than the nervous system (relies on the blood circulation for  communication) Endocrine glands – the organs of the endocrine system that produce and release  hormones into the blood (located throughout the body)  Hormones – the chemical messengers of the endocrine system Sexual activity, eating, sleeping, general physiological arousal and growth are heavily  influenced by the endocrine system The endocrine system is under the control of the hypothalamus, which in turn sends messages to the pituitary gland. This gland, sometimes described as the “master gland,” controls the other glands of the body. For example, during times of stress, the adrenal glad (which sits on top of the kidneys)  releases norepinephrine and epinephrine = triggers sympathetic nervous system 28
